utterances: Boy, we are in a real predicament, you know, and there's lots of discussion about whether or not we're in a civil war.
And quite frankly, I don't think any of it makes any difference.
Whatever it is, it's uncontrollable chaos.
We've lost the initiative.
And quite frankly, it didn't have to be that way.
But what's the choice, do you think, that confronts policy makers?

And I understand because you - I kind of set up the question in a leading way because you have been outspoken in expressing the idea that the United States has to do one thing or another at this point.
That's right.
You know, we are at a decision point, a crucial decision point.
And we have two options.
One, we can continue and to finish what we started in Iraq.
If that's the course of action that we select, we need a strategy.
It's not more of the same.
But leadership and a strategy that is communicated to the American people in such a way that we all understand the what and the why.
You know, this nation in the past four years has not been mobilized for war.
I'll tell you, when I came back from Germany in June and July of 2005, I was absolutely stunned that it was business as usual back home.
Now, remember, I had been gone for three years.
But I was absolutely stunned, as was my family and those around that were deployed with us, were stunned that when we got home this country was not mobilized for war.
Beyond the occasional bumper sticker and certainly people who were sending care packages and supporting troops that they knew, perhaps family members, beyond that there was nothing.
There was no national level mobilization.
There was no rationing system of any sort.
I don't think that's the way that you prosecute a war.
I think we're better than that.
And we are spending a billion and a half dollars a week.
We're spilling American blood in amounts that outrage me.
And it just didn't have to be that way.
On the other hand, if the decision is that we're not going to continue...
Hey, General - can I interrupt for just a moment?
We're hearing like a pounding, which we suspect might be you striking the desk in emphasis.
Is that true?
It may be.
Okay.
(Soundbite of laughter)
If that's the case, we don't want you to be any less emphatic.
Okay.
But if you could leave your hand out of it...
I'm with you.
I'm with you, Scott.
You know, if you look back to Ronald Reagan in 1980, you know, Reagan's positions were not that popular, but what people saw in him was leadership.
And I think what the Democrats have got to do is start leading and not be so concerned about momentary turns in the polls.
Hillary Clinton can't satisfy all the fractured constituencies of the Democratic Party.
But what the party requires now is someone to step forward as a leader and say this is where we should be, as a party.
That hasn't happened yet, and until it happens, the Democrats are always going to be in disarray.

Julianne, if you look at young voters, especially young voters of color, you find large numbers of independent voters; but because there are very few third parties or independent parties, most of those folks don't vote.
Should there be more of an effort to reach out and get those people involved?

And do you get any sense - obviously, we're still quite a ways off from the 2006 election, but with the House in play and the Senate possibly in play, do you get any sense that people are trying to reach these skeptical young voters?
I think there are small efforts, business I don't think they're significant enough, Farai.
There are some young people, I think, who are doing phenomenal things, and there are some who are connected with the Democratic Party and with the Republican Party.
But, as you say, the key thing is that young voters - almost half of them - are registering as independents.
They find no fealty with either party.
They're looking at issues.
They're not looking at people or parties.
They're really turned off by the partisan bickering and by the gridlock.
When you look at young African-Americans - very, very interesting - one of the issues that wedges them is that young African-Americans with children are interested in charter schools.
They're interested in educational alternatives because, by and large, they live in inner cities.
They're turned off by public education.
Those of us who are over a certain age - we won't say what - you know, who are public education advocates - as a young man said to me the other day, he said, you have neither chick nor child.
You don't have a dog in this fight.
But I think I do because I care about educational quality, and that's one of the issues where Dems are losing.
For example, young African-Americans, young people who are not looking at ideology, but how does politics affect the day-to-day aspects of my life?
And so I think that we've really got to get those folks involved in the practical aspects of politics, and I don't see Democrats spending enough time, effort, energy or money in that.
The community that I think is interesting, Farai, is the blogging community, which skews young.
And I think that some of the things, like what's his name - Daily Cosis(ph) in his early 30's...
Marcus Malitsis(ph).
Yeah, dailycosis.com(ph).

But there's only one very noted African-American blogger and that's Chris Rabb at AfroNetizen, and so - but I think that that blogging community sort of speaks to young people's alienation with the way we do politics.
Yes, but, you know, there's a difference between self-interest and public interest.
And I do know that voters generally vote their self-interest.

But it is a disturbing trend that seems to me if young African-Americans - or for that matter, anybody who's young - who doesn't understand the context of history and the movement for public education - charter schools mostly are public schools - but there are an increasing number of young people who believe in vouchers, who do not understand the notion and the concept of the separation of church and state, for example.
And only because they want their children to have the best schools they can possibly get, and therefore, public bus funds should be put into sectarian schools.

And they don't really care about people's religion or if their children have to make the sign of the cross to get a, quote, unquote, ""quality education,"" but they should care, because the issues are bigger than just their children.
So we, who have a dog in this hunt, may not have children, but we do have children of all colors.
And we have a future of society we must care about.
But, Michael, what's wrong with somebody wanting their kid to have the best thing?
What's wrong with someone saying that I want my child to have the best education there is, and I think that public education has failed, so let me see what the alternatives are?
There is nothing wrong with that, but if you want an alternative to public education, then you pay for it.
Don't ask the public, the taxpayers, to pay for your child to go to a private a school or a religious school.
Well, you know, one thing that that raises a question is, who's money is it?
And I think it eventually becomes the money of the individual, and the individual taxpayer should have some say in how their tax dollars are spent.
But I think part of what you have to do is you have to lower the altitude of political discourse.
You know, you have to remember that all politics really is local.
And I think if you want to engage young people, you have to engage them at a level that's meaningful to them.
We often have these lofty discussions and we have these intellectual debates, but I think most people engage in a political process at home, where they can see it and feel it.
Many of the debates in Congress have no meaning for the American public, because they can't feel it.
But they can feel the effects of what's going on in their individual communities, and counties and states.
Yeah.
And I think that's where we've made the mistake.
We've sort of tried to engage people at 40,000 feet, when we should be talking to them at ten.
Well that's what probably (inaudible)...
Well that's...
...was saying when he says, let's end this Iraq war by bringing back the draft.
Because that's how we ended the Vietnam War.
People were being drafted, and the young, middle class people and their families said oh, no!
That, and that's a real big issue.
And I'm sorry, I might be a little loud, but I want people to get the message.
I know they can see it, but I also want them to notice it and I don't want anybody's blood on our hands or my hands.
Well, Michael, Michael, hold on, let me, I have another issue that I just want to throw into this mix, although I know we do the whole show, or the whole segment on this.
When you speak about local politics, you're also not just talking about what are the intersections of federal, state, and local government.
You can also talk about who are the other players in the local political arena.
And in New Orleans - very interesting - the AFL-CIO plans to kick off a development investing a billion dollars in affordable housing and a new downtown hotel.
They are dipping onto a 40-year trust fund for the money, and the - basically, it's an implicit critique that government has not done enough, so this labor union is going to do it.
Michael, do you think that this is mainly good press for the union, or is this going to make a significant change?
Well, I've been in New Orleans so many times, and I have planned conventions in New Orleans.
You don't need another new downtown hotel.
What you need is a new town, completely, in New Orleans.
And this is a union, and when I think about it, when you go to New Orleans, there are no union hotels except for two: the Fairmont and Lowell's.
So New Orleans is not a union-friendly town.
So talk about self-interest, this is a union trying to get a new hotel -unionized hotel in New Orleans.
But I have to say that...
But they're not...
...I have to say that, you know, there's also the peril of haphazard development.
So we need a new town concept, and we should avoid low-income ghetto development.
We need mixed incoming housing, economic and racially so.
And I - it's to the point that they're building affording -affordable housing; I think that's good, but there has to be some plan at this.
Not just haphazard.
Julianne?
Well, there's just...
I think...
The planning process heretofore has sidelined the poor, has sidelined affordable issues, and has allowed the people with the money to weigh-in on how the planning is done.
So I very much welcome the AFL-CIO's incursion here.
I welcome it for any number of reasons.
First of all, the number of units of affordable housing that will be created.
Secondly, you know, New Orleans was a city that was 65 percent - the poverty rate there was so very high.
And I may misquote with 65 percent, but it was a very high poverty rate.
Eight-five percent of the kids were getting subsidized lunches in New Orleans' public schools.
So when you look at that poverty rate, you have to raise a question about what people were earning.
The casinos came in, non union, and ended up with a series of very low-wage jobs.
People were making a buck or two above the minimum wage.
That's all.
That does not alleviate poverty.

When unions say we're going to build 10,000 units of affordable housing with union workers, what they're saying is, you're not going to make $8 an hour, you're going to make $15 to $20, maybe even $30 an hour.
And I think that's a great thing for New Orleans.
Someone has to weigh in, and somehow, politically, people have not been able to get poor people systematically weighed in.
So I think that the AFL will do some of that.
Now, I will say, there's an element of truth in what Michael says, but only an element.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Always.
I mean, there obviously is some self-interest here.
I think that the labor movement has been battered in the public.
The well publicized split between the AFL-CIO and SCIU and the Teamsters has made unions look, you know, really irresponsible I think.
And this is a way for John Sweeney and his team to polish their image.
Yes.
But, hey, if polishing their image trickles down to 10,000 units of affordable housing, I say you can polish your image anytime on my dime.
